title: Tradesman ‘set fire to new £375,000,000 building on cigarette break’
text:
A massive blaze burns on the roof of Auckland’s SkyCity centre (Michael Craig/New Zealand Herald photograph via AP)

A massive fire that broke out on the roof of a building which is still under construction may have started when a worker left a blow torch unattended during a cigarette break.

The fire at the SkyCity convention centre covered the city of Auckland, New Zealand, in thick black smoke at around 1pm local time today.

More than 20 fire crews battled the blaze that raged at the £350,000,000 building as authorities urged people to stay away.

According to a worker at the scene, the blaze may have been sparked by a torch used to heat and seal waterproofing material.

One of the torches may have been left unattended when another construction worker went for a smoke, local media reports.

Fire commander Dave Woon said the fast-moving blaze was ‘very challenging to fight’.

He said: ‘It is a large fire involving gas cylinders that started around the roof and guttering area and there is insulation on fire that appears to be straw making it a very challenging fire to extinguish.

The fire is said to have started on the roof(Provider: Steven Ivamy)

Fire crews are tirelessly working to put out the blaze (Michael Craig/New Zealand Herald photograph via AP)

He added: ‘We are currently fighting the fire in an offensive attack mode.

‘We are not on top of the fire, but with the resources that have just arrived we should be able to make progress.’

SkyCity had to evacuate its iconic tower and casino as a result of the fire.

There have been no reports of deaths or injuries but Stuff.nz said a firefighter was sent to hospital for an unrelated medical event.

Auckland Emergency Management sent a text message alert to phones across Auckland that advised people to stay indoors and keep their windows close due to the thick black smoke covering the city centre.

The Auckland sky is covered in smoke(@CR0ckDraaaW / Twitter)

The authorities are advising people to avoid the area and stay indoors(@CeeBee_NZ / Twitter)

A number of roads surrounding the area were closed and bus services diverted, bringing the centre of New Zealand’s largest city to a standstill.

The New Zealand International Convention Centre was scheduled to open next year and was expected to accommodate more than 3,000 people at conferences.

Plans include a new 300-room hotel being built next to the centre. Work began on the site in 2015.
